testimony.threat_quote: if she had been allowed to treat her she would have healed her, but she risked being ill for the rest of her life

timeline.subject: PG des Vosges
timeline.details: PG informed of Jennon's activities and took steps to have her arrested and interrogated

timeline.subject: Jennon Villemin
timeline.details: Taken at village of Bazegney by prévôt of Mirecourt on orders of PG des Vosges

timeline.subject: PG des Vosges
timeline.details: PG (Dumenil) asks for interrogation; requests questions about Anthoine Grevillon and areas of Bussang and le Thillot

timeline.subject: Jennon Villemin
timeline.details: By George Gerard, lieutenant en la prévôté de Mirecourt

timeline.subject: Jennon Villemin
timeline.details: Confrontations with witnesses; PG asks for confrontations

timeline.subject: Jennon Villemin
timeline.details: Escaped from prison by making hole in wall; negotiated drops of 8 and 12 feet

timeline.subject: Jennon Villemin
timeline.details: Recaptured after 3 days hiding in woods; injured from escape

timeline.subject: Jennon Villemin
timeline.details: PG asks for question ordinaire to investigate superstitions and possible witchcraft

timeline.subject: Jennon Villemin
timeline.details: Change de Nancy declares her sufficiently convicted of superstitious actions, frauds and deceptions; sentence of whipping and perpetual banishment

timeline.subject: Jennon Villemin
timeline.details: Formal sentence pronounced and carried out

torture.restrictions: Request denied; Change de Nancy proceeded directly to sentence without torture

notable_quotes.speaker: Claudon femme Claudon Borain (witness 3)
notable_quotes.french: Jehennon je me descharge de mon pellerinage et vous en charge
notable_quotes.english: Jennon I discharge myself of my pilgrimage and charge you with it
notable_quotes.context: Transfer of pilgrimage obligation through ritual formula

notable_quotes.speaker: Barbon femme Bastien Saulnier (witness 5)
notable_quotes.context: Warning about husband's drinking if he did not amend before Easter

notable_quotes.speaker: Margueritte veuve Jean Husson (witness 6)
notable_quotes.french: ung diable au corps, une coleuvre de la longueur de son bras, et ung crapeau
notable_quotes.english: a devil in the body, a snake the length of her arm, and a toad
notable_quotes.context: Jennon's diagnosis of daughter Anne's illness

notable_quotes.speaker: Idotte femme Claudin Henryot (witness 12)
notable_quotes.french: Dieu y ait part, a la bonne heure puisse je entrer ceans
notable_quotes.english: May God have part in it, at the good hour may I enter here

notable_quotes.speaker: Marie femme Demenge Lorrain (witness 15)
notable_quotes.french: Ah Genot, Genot, Genot tu veulx estre bien malade Genot
notable_quotes.english: Ah Genot, Genot, Genot you want to be very sick Genot
notable_quotes.context: Jennon speaking to the fire/cauldron, naming a witch as cause of illness

notable_quotes.speaker: Marie femme Demenge Lorrain (witness 15)
notable_quotes.french: Au nom de dieu et de la Vierge Marie
notable_quotes.english: In the name of God and the Virgin Mary
notable_quotes.context: Said three times while measuring patient with thread

notable_quotes.speaker: Jennon Villemin
notable_quotes.french: parce que les femmes faisoient mieulx les pelerinages que les hommes
notable_quotes.english: because women made better pilgrimages than men
notable_quotes.context: Explaining why she preferred to make pilgrimages herself rather than send men

notable_quotes.speaker: Change de Nancy
notable_quotes.french: d'avoir par action superstitieuse commis plusieurs affronteries et tromperies
notable_quotes.english: having by superstitious action committed several frauds and deceptions

relationships.evidence_text: daughter of Claudon Vuillemin of Velaucourt
married Nicolas Breton of Liepvre, a doctor; husband only lived 5 and a half years
her brother Nicolas, forester for duke at Tencey
had promised to marry her and slept with her for 2 nights; told Serrurier he was her brother; stole 2 écus from house
femme Georgeot Gerard Dol
femme Claudon Borain
femme Didier Goudot
femme Bastien Saulnier
veuve Jean Husson, bourgeois de Mirecourt
illness of daughter Anne
femme Jean Laurens, drappier bourgeois de Mirecourt
veuve Didier Cochien, marechal de Mirecourt
femme Jean Gardel, de Mirecourt
femme Demenge Aulbertin, drappier de Mirecourt
femme George Ruzet, bourgeois de Mirecourt
femme Claudin Henryot, de Mirecourt
femme Pierrot Jean, marchal de Mirecourt
femme Claude Noel, de Mirecourt
femme Demenge Lorrain
Her brother Jean Husson, dyer
servante a Demenge Lorrain
veuve Nicolas Mengenot, bourgeois de Mirecourt
femme Thieriot Vuillemin, marchand bourgeois de Mirecourt

economic_context.details: Jennon charged fees for her healing services ranging from 2 écus to 12 francs, plus additional payments for masses and materials. Witness 15 never paid promised 8 francs.

harms_catalog.harm_description: illness in petit ventre (lower abdomen); diagnosed as maladie St Bernard
harms_catalog.method_alleged: failed healing treatment with herbs, white wine, candles, and pilgrimage

harms_catalog.harm_description: 7 years of illness with something moving in body, rising to throat threatening to stifle her
harms_catalog.method_alleged: failed healing with candles, pilgrimage, stones in red wine

harms_catalog.harm_description: more than a year of illness with something moving around body; diagnosed as mal de St Genois le grand
harms_catalog.method_alleged: failed healing with candles, pilgrimage to Germany, herbal drinks, expected to vomit out lizard

harms_catalog.harm_description: longstanding stomach complaint
harms_catalog.method_alleged: failed healing with candles, pilgrimage to Chapelle de la Croix in Germany, scarf ceremony, bread and wine

harms_catalog.harm_description: debauches, excessive drinking
harms_catalog.method_alleged: failed cure with pilgrimage and drinks made with wine, herbs, pepper and ginger

harms_catalog.harm_description: had devil in body, a snake the length of her arm, and a toad
harms_catalog.method_alleged: diagnosis by Jennon; curé forbade treatment

harms_catalog.harm_description: stomach trouble
harms_catalog.method_alleged: candles, pilgrimages to Notre Dame de Syon and Notre Dame aux Trois Espines, crown of pimprenelle; curé forbade use

harms_catalog.harm_description: bad leg; diagnosed as mal de St Mimin; leg became swollen from ointment, nearly died
harms_catalog.method_alleged: ointments with lard, eggs, blessed candles, oil, herbs; horsedung in stocking taken on pilgrimage

harms_catalog.harm_description: longstanding stomach trouble; said it was given by relative of her husband
harms_catalog.attributed_to: parent of her husband (according to Jennon)
harms_catalog.method_alleged: drink with wine and herbs that caught fire during preparation

harms_catalog.harm_description: trouble with tongue; said illness was given to her
harms_catalog.method_allocated: drink that caught fire, pilgrimage to Bel Bernard with surplice ritual

harms_catalog.harm_description: illness in chest and ribs; diagnosed as cruel mal, point in heart given at return from Bouzemont
harms_catalog.method_alleged: wine that caught alight, pilgrimage to Beau Bernard

harms_catalog.victim_name: small son of Idotte femme Claudin Henryot
harms_catalog.harm_description: could not walk straight; diagnosed as worms in his back; said someone made him ill and if he died someone else would fall ill
harms_catalog.method_alleged: pilgrimage to Beau Bernard, ointments and baths with herbs

harms_catalog.harm_description: lip ailment treated 30 years earlier

harms_catalog.victim_name: daughter of Barbon femme Claude Noel
harms_catalog.harm_description: sick daughter
harms_catalog.method_alleged: drink made from wine and herbs, no effect

harms_catalog.harm_description: unspecified illness; Jennon named witch Genot as cause, said he gave the illness
harms_catalog.method_alleged: candles, pilgrimage to Virgin far off, herbs and wine that caught fire, measuring with thread

harms_catalog.victim_name: daughter of Jeannon veuve Nicolas Mengenot
harms_catalog.harm_description: jaundice
harms_catalog.method_alleged: egg with wheat grains ritual, pilgrimage to Notre Dame, drink - no healing

harms_catalog.harm_description: had been bewitched according to Jennon
longstanding stomach trouble; if herbs caught light someone had given her the illness
harms_catalog.method_alleged: pilgrimage to ND de Lamet, herbs in white wine, 5 roots to boil

harms_catalog.harm_description: bad leg requiring amputation; Jennon cured by drawing bone out
harms_catalog.method_alleged: ointment with lard, hemp oil, blessed candle, crosswort leaves, wheat leaven - successfully healed by Jennon

harms_catalog.harm_description: stomach complaint
harms_catalog.method_alleged: drink with white wine and hart's tongue herb - successfully healed by Jennon

material_culture.context: Used repeatedly in divination rituals to identify which saints were involved in illness; 9 candles used in multiple cases
Used to make medicinal drinks with herbs; often boiled and reduced
Used to heat stones from pilgrimage for medicinal drink; also used in other healing preparations
Multiple types used: verveine, langue de cerf (hart's tongue), saincq, becont, verfeuil, persin, racine de fenouil, saulge croisée (crosswort)
Garment made with points sewn on it for pilgrimage rituals; transferred to Jennon with verbal formula
Used as substitute surplice for Virgin's child in pilgrimage rituals; had to have specific number of points sewn on
Rosary/prayer beads taken on pilgrimage to be blessed; Marie femme George Ruzet lost cross off hers
Taken on pilgrimage to be blessed; used in healing rituals
Brought back from pilgrimage sites; rye bread from Germany
Used in ointment recipes
Used in ointments for healing bad leg
Used in ointments and in wheat grain divination ritual
Used in ointments; huyle de cheneveux (hemp oil)
Ingredient in drink to cure husband's drinking
Ingredient in drink to cure husband's drinking
5 grains placed in egg and thrown on fire for divination
5 small stones from well where Virgin rested, brought back and put in red wine
Bought to offer on altar during pilgrimage
Put in stocking with 5 eggs to take on pilgrimage to St Mimin; placed by feet of saint
Man's cloth stocking used to carry horsedung and eggs on pilgrimage
Used to measure patient three times with religious formula
Given to make dress for Virgin's child; witness 2 received 14 aulnes (Jennon made chemises for herself and Jean Ré)
Crown/wreath of salad burnet to put on stomach; curé forbade its use
Wheat leaven used in ointment recipe
Votive offerings at chapel - room full of wax children with 3-5 pieces of silver at their necks
2 écus paid by Demenge Serrurier; stolen by Jean Ré
Currency used for payments; fees ranged from 2 to 12 francs
Smaller denomination currency; 15 gros, 18 gros, 30 gros mentioned

Pilgrimage destination

Pilgrimage destination

spatial_references.context: Pilgrimage destination in Germany
Pilgrimage destination for leg ailment; horsedung placed by feet of saint
Saint identified in candle divination
Unknown man went on pilgrimage there and never returned
Location of mal de St Genois le grand pilgrimage; far into Germany; needed German speaker
PG asked if Jennon had frequented this area; she denied it
PG asked if Jennon had frequented this area; she denied it
Furthest Jennon claimed to have traveled
Where Jennon bought cheeses during husband's lifetime
Where Jennon bought cheeses during husband's lifetime
Marie femme George Ruzet given illness at return from this place
Road between Rambervillier and Romont where Jennon saw sky split
Near Notre Dame des Trois Epis
Vaxoncourt located by the Moselle river
Near La Maix shrine; Jennon hid in woods by day for 2 days after escape; passed through woods between Ramberviller and Romont

spatial_references.place_name: cross where a man had been killed
spatial_references.context: Where black dog followed Jennon for an hour during pilgrimage
Where Jennon was staying when witness 6 consulted her
Where Jennon was staying when witness 8 consulted her
Where Jennon was staying when multiple witnesses consulted her; herbs found there
Where Jennon was staying at Christmas when witness 5 heard of her
Jennon slept there for 3 weeks
Where Jennon was held; escaped by making hole in wall with 8 foot and 12 foot drops

historical_context.military_details: Reference to 'Mansfeld' - Jennon left Liepvre 13 months before trial (around May-June 1624) because of Mansfeld. This refers to military activity by Count Ernst von Mansfeld during the Thirty Years' War.
weather_events: Very bad weather during 8-day pilgrimage by witness 2
animal_predation: Black dog followed Jennon for an hour after passing cross where man was killed
economic_hardship_indicators: Jennon hiding in woods by day and begging food at night after escape
religious_calendar_references: Before last Purification of Our Lady (February 2, 1625)

officials_named.name: George Gerard
officials_named.location: lieutenant en la prévôté de Mirecourt

officials_named.name: curé (unnamed)
officials_named.location: Multiple curés mentioned at various shrines and Mirecourt

legal_context.imprisonment_conditions: After recapture, surgeon advised life would be in danger if returned to prison due to injuries from escape, so she was put under guard of a woman near prison for 8 days

hearsay_chains.content: Had heard of treatment of Margueritte and called Jennon in for own complaint

emotional_state_notes: During interrogation admitted virtually all details with only small variants and less emphasis on witchcraft
During confrontations accepted virtually everything witnesses said, declaring it was the truth
Escaped from prison by making hole in wall and negotiating dangerous drops of 8 and 12 feet
After escape hid in woods by day and begged food at night
Injured during escape; surgeon warned life in danger if returned to prison

third_parties.name: Mme de Bouzellon
third_parties.context: Jennon worked in her service for 6 years near Ramberviller; claimed she taught Jennon healing methods with ointments

third_parties.name: Anne
third_parties.context: Daughter of Margueritte veuve Jean Husson; Jennon said she had devil, snake, and toad in body; curé forbade treatment

third_parties.name: Jean Passans
third_parties.context: Jennon was at his house when witness 6 consulted her; Jennon told his wife that one of his relatives wished her ill

third_parties.name: Nicolas Lolbion, pasticier
third_parties.context: Jennon was at his house when witness 8 consulted her

third_parties.name: Pierrot le Saulx
third_parties.context: Jennon stayed at his house; multiple witnesses consulted her there; herbs found in his house; wife recommended Jennon to witness 11

third_parties.name: Jean Ré of Nomexey
third_parties.context: Promised to marry Jennon and slept with her for 2 nights; she told Serrurier he was her brother; stole 2 écus from house; Jennon made chemises for him with cloth from witness 2

third_parties.name: Jean Beurion
third_parties.context: His child at Porthsieux had bad leg requiring amputation; Jennon cured by drawing bone out with ointment

third_parties.name: Demenge de Ville
third_parties.context: Of Bazegney; came with horse to fetch Jennon at Christmas to treat his daughter's stomach complaint; she recovered

third_parties.name: Jean Husson (dyer)
third_parties.context: Told his sister Marie that Jennon was in his house and might bring healing

third_parties.name: Genot
third_parties.context: Named by Jennon as witch who caused illness to witness 15 and to daughter of Jean Husson; Jennon called his name three times over cauldron

third_parties.name: Anthoine Grevillon
third_parties.context: PG asked if Jennon knew him; she denied meeting him but knew he had been burned because Mre Nicolas told her

third_parties.name: Mre Nicolas
third_parties.context: Told Jennon that Grevillon had been burned

third_parties.name: Nicolas Breton of Liepvre
third_parties.context: A doctor living at Ramberviller; hasty marriage over weekend; lived 5.5 years; had three sons who all died very young

third_parties.name: Nicolas Vuillemin
third_parties.context: Forester for duke at Tencey; Jennon's illegitimate son by unknown man lived with him

third_parties.name: unknown man
third_parties.context: Promised to marry Jennon in presence of curé; never returned from pilgrimage to St Jacques; child born more than 3 years before trial

third_parties.name: curé at Liepvre
third_parties.context: Knew Jennon and Nicolas Breton were good people; allowed hasty marriage for 5 francs dispensing bans; witnessed promise of marriage from unknown man

third_parties.name: curé at Mirecourt
third_parties.context: Spoke to Jennon about treating witness 6's daughter, told her to retire discreetly, forbade treatment; forbade witness 7 from using crown of pimprenelle

third_parties.name: curé of la Croix
third_parties.context: Blessed chapelet, salt, bread and wine for witness 11; told her to take them over 9 day period

third_parties.name: doctors, apothecaries, and surgeons
third_parties.context: Called in to judge whether herbs Jennon carried were genuine or counterfeit superstitious

third_parties.name: surgeon (unnamed)
third_parties.context: Advised that Jennon's life would be in danger if returned to prison after recapture due to injuries

third_parties.name: sergent and 2 men
third_parties.context: Searched for Jennon after escape; unsuccessful for 2 days; arrested her in village on third day and brought her back on cart

third_parties.name: woman who lived near prison
third_parties.context: Jennon put under her guard for 8 days after recapture due to injuries

extraction_metadata.notes: This is an unusual case focused on superstitious healing practices rather than traditional witchcraft accusations. Jennon was a folk healer/cunning woman who performed pilgrimages and used herbal remedies, candles, and ritual objects. She was not accused of causing harm through witchcraft, but rather of fraudulent and superstitious healing practices. The case involved 18 witnesses who were her clients/patients. Notable features: (1) No typical witch trial elements like sabbat, devil's pact, or maleficia; (2) Jennon escaped prison and was recaptured after 3 days; (3) Sentence was banishment and whipping, not death; (4) Case shows intersection of folk healing, popular religion, and official church disapproval; (5) Rich material culture details about healing practices, pilgrimages, and ritual objects; (6) Economic aspects prominent - Jennon charged substantial fees for services; (7) Military context reference to Mansfeld indicates Thirty Years' War disruption; (8) Change de Nancy showed leniency, rejecting PG's request for torture.
